bioghist.p: The University of Michigan Peace Corps office helps students pursue service opportunities with the Peace Corps and disseminates information about the organization to the campus community. The history of Peace Corps activities at the University of Michigan dates back to the conception and creation of the Peace Corps itself. In September 1960, Senator and then presidential candidate John F. Kennedy asked Dr. Samuel Hayes, UM Professor of Economics, to draft a report on a potential peace corps. During a campaigning trip in Ann Arbor on October 14, 1960, Senator and presidential candidate John F. Kennedy challenged the students present to spend time giving international service, the idea that forms the basis of the Peace Corps.

The response from Michigan students was more than just favorable. Interested students formed a group called Americans Committed to World Responsibility (ACWR), in support of the idea of a peace corps. Around 250 students signed petitions agreeing to volunteer, and the ACWR traveled to Ohio, where they met Kennedy at the airport and delivered the petitions in person.

The positive response of Michigan students provided the needed momentum that turned the peace corps from an idea into a reality, and on March 1, 1961, the Peace Corps was officially created through an Executive Order. But Michigan's contributions weren't finished. Over 2000 Michigan alumni have served in the Peace Corps and contributed in other significant ways to the organization.

In 2010, the Peace Corps turned 50, and the University held a series of activities to celebrate this milestone and the University's role in the birth of the Corps. Among the events was a National Symposium focusing on the future of international service, ceremonies on the Michigan Union steps where Kennedy addressed the students in 1960, guest speakers, photo exhibits, and more.

arrangement.p: The collection is divided into two series, Fiftieth Anniversary Videos and Archived Website.

scopecontent.p: The Peace Corps Office (University of Michigan) records contain information about the unit as well as the role of the University of Michigan in the development of the Peace Corps.

scopecontent.p: Fiftieth Anniversary Videos, consists of videos of events held to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of Senator Kennedy's speech at the Michigan Union. These videos were downloaded from YouTube.

did.unittitle: First Ceremony on Michigan Union Steps 2010

odd.p: (The 2 a.m. October 14, 2010 celebration of the remarks by John Kennedy 50 years ago, that led to the formation of the Peace Corps. The program included a performance by the UM Educational Theater Company (UMetc) and featured guest speakers Aaron Williams, Director, Peace Corps; Alan Guskin, student in 1960 who advocated for the creation of the Peace Corps; and Steven Weinberg, student and founder of Will Work For Food.)

did.unittitle: Second Ceremony on Michigan Union Steps 2010

odd.p: (The 11 a.m., October 14, 2010, celebration of the remarks by John Kennedy that led to the formation of the Peace Corps 50 years earlier, which took place on the steps of the Michigan Union. Special guest speakers included former Kennedy aide and architect of the Peace Corps, Sen. Harris Wofford; Jack Hood Vaughn, second director of the Peace Corps and U-M alumnus; Aaron Williams, current director of the Peace Corps; Marnee DeVine, first cousin of Pres. Kennedy; Julia Darlow, chair, U-M Board of Regents and Mary Sue Coleman, U-M President.)

did.unittitle: National Symposium: The Future of International Service

odd.p: (Welcome and opening remarks of the National Symposium of the 50th Anniversary Peace Corps Celebrations, held on October 13, 2010 at the University of Michigan. Welcome remarks are given by Susan M. Collins, Joan and Sanford Weill Dean of Public Policy, Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy, and the opening remarks are given by The Honorable Harris L. Wofford, former U.S. Senator (PA), Special Assistant to Pres. Kennedy on Civil Rights, and Peace Corps Architect and Special Representative to Africa.)

did.unittitle: First Panel Session -- Overview of the Current Landscape 2010

odd.p: (First panel session of the National Symposium of the 50th Anniversary Peace Corps Celebrations, held on October 13, 2010 at the University of Michigan. Moderator is Lex Rieffel, Nonresident Senior Fellow, Global Development and Economy Program, Brookings Institution. Panelists are Stanley S. Litow, President, IBM International Foundation and Vice President for Corporate Citizenship; Michelle Nunn, CEO, Points of Light Institute, Co-Founder HandsOn Network; and Steven C. Rosenthal, Executive Director, Cross Cultural Solutions, and CEO, Building Bridges Coalition)

did.unittitle: Second Panel Session -- The Impact of International Service: What are the Lessons? 2010

odd.p: (Second panel session of the National Symposium of the 50th Anniversary Peace Corps Celebrations, held on October 13, 2010 at the University of Michigan. The moderator is James Jackson, Director, Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan. The panelists are manda McBride, Assistant Professor of Social Work, Director of the Gephardt Institute for Public Service, and Research Director of the Center for Social Development, Washington University; Roopal Shah, Executive Director and Co-Founder, Indicorps; and Carrie Hessler-Radelet, Deputy Director, Peace Corps.)

did.unittitle: Third Panel Session -- New Initiatives and Policy Proposals 2010

odd.p: (Third panel session of the National Symposium for the 50th Anniversary Peace Corps Celebration at the University of Michigan, held on October 13, . Moderator is Kevin Quigley, President, National Peace Corps Association. Panelists are John M. Bridgeland, President and CEO, Civic Enterprises; Stephen P. Groff, Deputy Director, Development Co-operation Directorate OECD; and Sonal Shah, Director, White House Office of Social Innovation and Civic Participation.)

did.unittitle: Fourth Panel Session -- Role of Universities 2010

odd.p: (Fourth panel session of the National Symposium of the 50th Anniversary Peace Corps Celebrations, held on October 13, 2010 at the University of Michigan. Moderator is Alan Guskin, University President Emeritus, Antioch University and former Chancellor, University of Wisconsin-Parkside. Panelists are Mary Sue Coleman, President, University of Michigan; and M. Peter McPherson, President, Association of Public and Land Grant Universities and former President, Michigan State University.)

did.unittitle: Closing Plenary and Keynote: "The Future of the Peace Corps" 2010

odd.p: (Closing plenary and keynote session of the National Symposium of the 50th Anniversary Peace Corps Celebrations, held on October 13, 2010 at the University of Michigan. Speaker is Aaron Williams, Director, Peace Corps. He is introduced by Mary Sue Coleman, President, University of Michigan.)

did.unittitle: The Passing of the Torch Promotional Video 2010

odd.p: (Promotional video for 60 min documentary The Passing of the Torch - The University of Michigan, JFK and the Peace Corps. The documentary was broadcast during the 50th Anniversary Celebrations in October, 2010, at the University of Michigan.)

scopecontent.p: The Archived Website series documents the history of the creation of the Peace Corps and the fiftieth anniversary events. Content includes important news and announcements, stories of volunteers, and other facts and information relating to the creation and history of the Peace Corps at the University of Michigan. Starting in 2011, this archived website will be captured on a regular, ongoing basis as part of the University of Michigan Web Archives, hosted at http://webarchives.cdlib.org/a/universityofmichigan/.
